questions.text: People who know how I'm really doing emotionally (not just 'fine') are ...

answers.4: several — they know the real state
answers.5: my inner circle — full emotional access
answers.2: maybe one — and even that's limited
answers.3: a few — in certain seasons or areas

questions.text: People I can cry, rage, or despair in front of without shame are ...

answers.4: several — they can hold my emotions
answers.5: my safe people — complete emotional honesty
answers.2: maybe one — and it's still uncomfortable
answers.3: a few — in the right circumstances
answers.1: none — I don't show that to anyone

questions.text: My ability to provide emotional presence for others (hold their emotions) is ...

answers.4: good — I can usually hold space
answers.5: strong — I'm a safe place for others' emotions
answers.3: moderate — I can do it sometimes
answers.1: poor — I fix, flee, or freeze

questions.text: My emotional friendships challenging me to grow (not just comfort) is ...
questions.principle: True fellowship transforms, not just supports

answers.4: regular — they push me to grow
answers.1: not happening — just comfort or nothing

questions.text: Sharing my emotional history (pain, trauma) with people who've earned trust is ...

answers.4: substantial — key people know the story
answers.5: complete — my trusted circle knows it all
answers.3: partial — some people know some things
answers.1: not happening — no one knows that

remediation.advice: Emotional fellowship is the hardest for many (especially men). It requires vulnerability that feels dangerous. But isolation guarantees you'll carry your emotional burdens alone, which eventually breaks you. Find one safe person. Share one real thing. Build from there.

scripture.text: Rejoice with those who rejoice, weep with those who weep.
